title: Little girl in wheelchair left traumatised after she's told she shouldn't be alive
text:

A sick thug told a four-year-old girl in a wheelchair she was a "drain on society" and shouldn't be alive.

Little Quinn Ross was left "traumatised" after the shameless lout approached her, her mum Emma and ten-year-old brother Alex in an alleyway.

Emma, 32, managed to push the man away and police in Cheshunt, Hertfordshire, are now investigating the hate crime .

"The man was yelling in her face, saying she shouldn’t have been born, she was a drain on the NHS, a drain on society and that I should have had her aborted if I’d known she was going to be disabled," mum-of-four Emma said.

"It was appalling.

"I pushed him away, power-walked off to school and it was the school who phoned the police."

(Image: south bedsnews agency_sbna_fairl)

Quinn has Perthes' disease, a rare childhood condition which affects the hip. It makes it painful for her to walk.

The sickening abuse has left Quinn "scared of men" and she is now having counselling.

Emma added: "Quinn is now scared of men and doesn’t like going out in her wheelchair.

"It left her feeling very angry at the world, but we’ve had a lot of support."

A spokesman for Hertfordshire Police said this week: "A four year old girl from Cheshunt who was verbally abused on her way to school because she was in a wheelchair has been supported by specialist police officers.

"Quinn Ross, who suffers from a rare condition called Perthes’ disease, which affects the top of the thigh bone in the hip joint, was in an alleyway when a man shouted at her."

PC Terasa Holden, a hate crime officer for Herts Police , said the offence - which took place last month - has been classified as a disability hate crime, adding: "A hate crime is when someone is targeted because of their disability or learning difficulties, race, religion, beliefs or sexuality.

"No one should worry about leaving home and facing abuse, particularly a little girl who is in too much pain to walk to school because of a rare medical condition.

"My colleagues and I have worked to support Quinn and her family and hope other people will come forward and report this kind of crime.

"We want people to know that we take all reports of hate crime very seriously and will always investigate.”
